Stvara zakonodavne i institucionalne zaštitne mehanizme koji sprječavaju ponavljanje, pretvarajući jednokratni skandal u trajno sistemsko poboljšanje
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost za hitne mjere odgovornosti (smjene, istražna komisija) — ove zahtijevaju samo političku volju, ne zakonodavno djelovanje. Srednja do visoka izvodljivost za zakonodavne izmjene, s obzirom da bi konsenzus između stranaka o izvršenju mjera protiv organizovanog kriminala trebalo da bude ostvariv čak i u fragmentiranom parlamentu Crne Gore. Diplomatsko angažovanje sa Briselom je odmah izvodljivo i već je trebalo da počne. Primarna prepreka nije institucionalni kapacitet već politička volja na najvišem nivou — upravo varijabla koju odsustvo premijera iz zemlje dovodi u pitanje. Ako se premijer vrati i posveti ovom okviru, sprovođenje u predloženim rokovima je realno.

assessments.summary_mne: Skandal sa bjegstvom Medenice predstavlja težak udarac na kredibilitet Crne Gore u procesu pristupanja EU, direktno ugrožavajući napredak zemlje u Poglavljima 23 (Pravosuđe i temeljna prava) i 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost) — dva poglavlja koja je Evropska komisija dosljedno identifikovala kao ključne pokazatelje za pristupnu putanju Crne Gore. Neuspjeh vlade da spriječi bjekstvo osuđenog pripadnika organizovanog kriminala, dodatno otežan odsustvom značajnih mjera odgovornosti, institucionalnom šutnjom i odlaskom premijera iz zemlje tokom krize nacionalne bezbjednosti, šalje razoran signal Briselu da infrastruktura vladavine prava Crne Gore ostaje fundamentalno nepouzdana.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj skandal je među najštetnijim dešavanjima za proces pristupanja Crne Gore EU u posljednjih nekoliko godina, pogađajući u samo srce Poglavlja 23 i 24 — poglavlja na kojima počiva cijela pristupna hronologija. Glavna briga ministarstva je da će Evropska komisija citirati ovu epizodu kao dokaz sistemskog nazadovanja vladavine prava u svom sljedećem Izvještaju o napretku, potencijalno zaustavljajući ili poništavajući godine pregovaračkih dostignuća. Vlada mora odmah uspostaviti nezavisnu istragu, implementirati konkretne mjere odgovornosti i proaktivno se angažovati sa Briselom kako bi spriječila trajnu štetu za kandidaturu Crne Gore.
key_concerns_mne: Direktna i teška šteta za pokazatelje Poglavlja 23 (Pravosuđe i temeljna prava), s obzirom da je istorijska presuda za organizovani kriminal postala neizvršiva zbog institucionalnog neuspjeha
Katastrofalan gubitak kredibiliteta po pitanju Poglavlja 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost), pri čemu bjekstvo demonstrira fundamentalnu nesposobnost u upravljanju policijom i sektorom bezbjednosti
Neodgovor vlade — bez razrješenja, bez nezavisne istrage, bez konkretnih korektivnih mjera — Evropska komisija će tumačiti kao odsustvo političke volje za reformu vladavine prava
Odlazak premijera u UAE tokom aktivne krize nacionalne bezbjednosti signalizira neangažovanost u reformskim prioritetima na najvišem političkom nivou
Rizik od negativne revizije efikasnosti finansiranja IPA III i potencijalnog pooštravanja uslovljenosti za alokacije u sektoru vladavine prava
Erozija statusa Crne Gore kao predvodnika među kandidatima sa Zapadnog Balkana, sa potencijalnim efektima prelivanja na političku dinamiku proširenja EU
Odbijanje direktora policije da podnese ostavku uprkos očiglednom operativnom neuspjehu potkopava okvir odgovornosti koji Brisel zahtijeva kao preduslov za dalji napredak u poglavljima
Javno ismijavanje policije od strane bjegунca na nacionalnoj televiziji i društvenim mrežama pojačava reputacionu štetu na međunarodnom nivou i biće istaknuto u izvještajima Komisije
Zahtjevi civilnog društva za krivičnom istragom o policijskim neuspjesima, ako se ignorišu, biće označeni kao nedovoljna saradnja sa nezavisnim nadzorom prema pokazateljima Poglavlja 23
recommendations_mne: Hitno uspostaviti nezavisnu komisiju za istragu sa vremenskim okvirom o okolnostima Medenikovog bjekstva, sa mandatom usklađenim sa EU standardima za nezavisan nadzor nad policijom — i proaktivno podijeliti njen mandat i sastav sa Evropskom komisijom
Zahtijevati ostavku ili razrješenje direktora policije i svih drugih zvaničnika sa direktnom nadzornom odgovornošću za neuspjeh izvršenja kućnog pritvora, kao minimalnu kredibilnu mjeru odgovornosti

Angažovati Delegaciju Evropske komisije u Podgorici i DG NEAR u Briselu kroz hitno brifovanje o korektivnim mjerama, prije nego što Komisija formira vlastitu procjenu — Crna Gora mora kontrolisati narativ

Zatražiti tehničku pomoć EU (TAIEX, twinning ili ekspertske misije) za hitnu reviziju režima kućnog pritvora i elektronskog nadzora, kako bi se demonstrirala posvećenost sistemskoj reformi umjesto ad hoc kontrole štete

Ubrzati amandmane na Zakonik o krivičnom postupku i Zakon o izvršenju krivičnih sankcija kako bi se zatvorile regulatorne praznine koje su omogućile da osuđena osoba sa kaznom od 10 godina ostane na kućnom pritvoru i naknadno pobjegne
Sazvati hitnu sjednicu Nacionalnog savjeta za evropske integracije kako bi se javno potvrdila međustranačka posvećenost reformi vladavine prava i pokazateljima Poglavlja 23/24

Izdati sveobuhvatnu javnu vladin saopštenje — ne samo jednu rečenicu od premijera — koja detaljno navodi specifične institucionalne neuspjehe, mjere odgovornosti i vremenski okvir za korektivne akcije, upućenu kako domaćoj javnosti tako i međunarodnim partnerima

Koordinirati sa Interpolom i EUROPOLOM na ministarskom nivou kako bi se demonstriralo aktivno proganjanje bjegунca sa visokim prioritetom, i objaviti ove napore kako bi se suprotstavio narativ o institucionalnoj pasivnosti

Naručiti nezavisnu reviziju svih visokoprofilnih slučajeva organizovanog kriminala i korupcije koji su trenutno u fazi izvršenja kako bi se identifikovale slične ranjivosti prije nego što proizvedu dodatne skandale

assessments.summary: The Medenica fugitive scandal and the government's failure to take concrete accountability measures represent a serious threat to Montenegro's fiscal and economic outlook. While not a fiscal decision per se, the institutional collapse it signals — a convicted organized crime figure mocking the state from social media while an Interpol Red Notice goes unenforced, combined with the PM's departure to the UAE and the Police Director's refusal to resign — directly undermines investor confidence, EU accession prospects (particularly Chapters 23 and 24 on judiciary and fundamental rights, and Chapter 5 on public procurement), sovereign risk perception, and the credibility of Montenegro's rule-of-law framework upon which all foreign capital flows ultimately depend.
assessments.executive_summary: This scandal poses a material threat to Montenegro's economic credibility and EU accession trajectory. The government's inaction risks credit rating downgrades, foreign investment flight, and stalled EU negotiations — all of which would directly damage the fiscal position. The Ministry of Finance urges immediate institutional accountability measures and a transparent remediation plan to contain economic fallout.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's economy is uniquely vulnerable to governance and rule-of-law perceptions. As a small, open, euroized economy without its own monetary policy or lender of last resort (no ECB membership despite using the euro), the country depends disproportionately on foreign direct investment (FDI), tourism confidence, and EU integration momentum to sustain growth, service public debt, and finance its current account deficit.

The Medenica scandal strikes at the heart of all three pillars.

First, on FDI and investor confidence: Montenegro's FDI stock is heavily concentrated in real estate, tourism, and energy — sectors where investors conduct thorough due diligence on rule-of-law and institutional stability. A government that cannot enforce a 10-year sentence against an organized crime figure, and whose Prime Minister responds by leaving for the UAE, sends a devastating signal. The World Bank's Doing Business indicators and the World Economic Forum's competitiveness rankings both weight institutional quality heavily. Montenegro already competes with Albania, Serbia, and North Macedonia for limited Western Balkan FDI; this scandal provides a concrete reason for investors to redirect capital elsewhere. Even a modest 5-10% decline in annual FDI inflows (which have ranged from €400-700 million in recent years) would have measurable fiscal consequences through reduced corporate tax receipts, lower VAT revenue from construction activity, and diminished employment.

Second, on EU accession and economic convergence: The European Commission's annual progress reports have consistently flagged Montenegro's track record on organized crime convictions and judicial effectiveness. This scandal will almost certainly feature prominently in the next report and could delay the provisional closure of Chapters 23 and 24 — which are effectively gatekeeping chapters for the entire accession process. Delayed accession means delayed access to EU structural and cohesion funds (potentially worth hundreds of millions of euros), delayed institutional upgrades that drive productivity, and sustained country risk premiums on sovereign borrowing. Montenegro's public debt, hovering around 60-65% of GDP, is manageable but sensitive to interest rate spreads; any perception of increased country risk directly raises debt servicing costs.

Third, on sovereign creditworthiness: Rating agencies (Moody's, S&P, Fitch) explicitly incorporate governance quality and institutional effectiveness into their sovereign rating methodologies. Montenegro currently sits at the lower end of investment-grade/upper speculative-grade territory. A sustained governance crisis that demonstrates inability to enforce basic judicial outcomes could trigger a negative outlook revision or downgrade. Each notch of downgrade increases borrowing costs on future Eurobond issuances by an estimated 25-50 basis points — on a debt stock exceeding €4 billion, this is non-trivial.

Fourth, on the budget itself: The direct fiscal costs of this scandal include the ongoing Interpol coordination, potential expanded police operations, and likely parliamentary inquiries. More importantly, the indirect costs — through depressed tax revenues from lower economic activity, potential delays in tourism season bookings if the scandal persists in international media, and increased borrowing costs — could amount to tens of millions of euros over a 12-24 month horizon.

The government's silence on accountability is itself a fiscal risk factor. Markets and rating agencies can absorb shocks; what they cannot absorb is uncertainty about whether institutions will self-correct. Every day without a clear remediation plan — dismissals, investigations, systemic reforms — compounds the economic damage.

Finally, the PM's trip to the UAE in the midst of this crisis raises specific fiscal concerns. If the visit was related to investment negotiations (as many such trips are), the timing severely weakens Montenegro's negotiating position. UAE-based sovereign wealth funds and investors will have noted the scandal and may demand more favorable terms, concessions, or guarantees — effectively transferring value from Montenegro's public balance sheet to private investors.
key_concerns: Severe damage to foreign investor confidence in Montenegro's rule of law, potentially reducing FDI inflows by 5-15% in 2026-2027, with cascading effects on corporate tax and VAT revenues

High risk of negative assessment in the European Commission's next progress report, potentially delaying Chapter 23/24 provisional closure and blocking access to pre-accession and eventual structural funds worth hundreds of millions of euros

Potential sovereign credit rating downgrade or negative outlook revision by Moody's, S&P, or Fitch, increasing debt servicing costs on Montenegro's ~€4 billion public debt by an estimated 25-50 basis points per notch
Weakened negotiating position with UAE and other Gulf investors during PM Spajic's visit, potentially resulting in less favorable terms for any investment deals or PPP agreements under negotiation
Prolonged institutional uncertainty depresses tourism booking confidence for the 2026 season — tourism contributes approximately 25% of GDP and is the single largest source of VAT revenue
Erosion of public trust in state institutions may increase tax non-compliance and informal economic activity, shrinking the tax base

Risk that the scandal provides political cover for delayed fiscal reforms (tax administration modernization, pension reform, public wage rationalization) as government attention is consumed by crisis management
recommendations: Issue an urgent fiscal impact assessment of the scandal, quantifying potential revenue losses from reduced FDI, tourism, and increased borrowing costs, to be presented to the Fiscal Council within 30 days

Demand immediate, concrete accountability actions (dismissals, criminal investigations into police failures) to signal institutional self-correction — framing this explicitly as an economic imperative, not just a security matter
Proactively engage with credit rating agencies to present the government's remediation plan before they initiate their own review; include fiscal resilience stress tests in the presentation

Accelerate engagement with the European Commission's DG NEAR to present a credible rule-of-law action plan, specifically targeting Chapter 23/24 benchmarks, to prevent the scandal from derailing the accession timeline
Commission an independent review of all ongoing PPP and investment negotiations with UAE entities to ensure Montenegro is not conceding excessive fiscal terms due to weakened bargaining position
Activate contingency budget planning that models a 5-10% FDI shortfall and a 3-5% tourism revenue decline scenario for 2026, identifying expenditure items that can be reprioritized

Strengthen the Anti-Money Laundering framework and asset recovery procedures — if Medenica has assets in Montenegro, initiate confiscation proceedings immediately to demonstrate that crime does not pay, and to recover funds for the state budget
Publicly commit to fiscal transparency measures (open budget portal updates, quarterly fiscal reports) to differentiate Montenegro's economic governance from the security governance failures

counter_proposal.title: Economic Crisis Containment and Institutional Credibility Restoration Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Finance would treat this scandal as a first-order economic emergency, not merely a security matter. Rather than government silence, we would immediately launch a three-track response: (1) a fiscal damage containment track with contingency budgeting and proactive rating agency engagement; (2) an institutional credibility track with concrete, time-bound accountability actions presented as prerequisites for economic stability; and (3) an EU accession acceleration track that turns the crisis into a reform catalyst by fast-tracking rule-of-law benchmarks under Chapters 23 and 24. The core principle is that every day of silence costs Montenegro real money — in higher borrowing costs, lost investment, and delayed EU integration — and the Finance Ministry should be leading the quantification and communication of these costs to force government action.
key_changes: Establish a cross-ministerial Economic Impact Task Force chaired by the Ministry of Finance to quantify and monitor the fiscal fallout from the scandal on a weekly basis
Mandate immediate dismissal of officials responsible for the enforcement failure, framed publicly as a necessary condition for maintaining Montenegro's investment-grade creditworthiness
Launch proactive 'roadshow' communications with top 20 foreign investors and key rating agency analysts within 14 days, presenting concrete remediation measures

Fast-track asset confiscation proceedings against Medenica under the Law on Seizure and Confiscation of Material Gain Derived from Criminal Activity, directing recovered assets to the consolidated budget
Prepare and publish a supplementary fiscal risk statement as an annex to the 2026 budget, transparently disclosing the potential fiscal impact of the institutional crisis
Conditionally link any new UAE investment agreements to independent due diligence review, ensuring the government's weakened position does not result in fiscally disadvantageous terms
expected_benefits: Containment of sovereign risk premium increase, potentially saving €10-20 million annually in debt servicing costs
Preservation of FDI pipeline by demonstrating institutional self-correction capacity to international investors
Prevention of EU accession timeline slippage, protecting access to an estimated €500+ million in pre-accession and eventual structural funds
Establishment of a precedent that fiscal impact analysis is a mandatory input into all government crisis responses
Strengthened fiscal transparency and accountability, improving Montenegro's position in global governance indices
Recovery of criminal assets for the state budget through expedited confiscation proceedings
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The fiscal impact assessment and contingency budgeting can be initiated immediately using existing Ministry of Finance capacity. Proactive rating agency engagement requires only political will and coordination. The main feasibility constraint is political — demanding dismissals and framing accountability as an economic imperative requires the Finance Minister to take a confrontational stance within the cabinet. However, the legal and institutional frameworks for asset confiscation, EU chapter benchmarking, and fiscal transparency already exist in Montenegrin law. The cross-ministerial task force would require a Government session decision but no legislative changes. The key risk is that the current political paralysis — exemplified by the PM's UAE departure — prevents even these administratively straightforward measures from being implemented in a timely manner.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Okvir za suzbijanje ekonomske krize i obnovu institucionalnog kredibiliteta
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo finansija bi tretiralo ovaj skandal kao ekonomsku krizu prvog reda, a ne samo kao sigurnosni problem. Umjesto vladine šutnje, odmah bismo pokrenuli odgovor na tri nivoa: (1) nivo suzbijanja fiskalne štete sa planiranjem za nepredviđene situacije i proaktivnim angažovanjem rejting agencija; (2) nivo institucionalnog kredibiliteta sa konkretnim, vremenski ograničenim mjerama odgovornosti predstavljenim kao preduslovi za ekonomsku stabilnost; i (3) nivo ubrzanja pristupanja EU koji pretvara krizu u katalizator reformi ubrzavanjem ispunjavanja kriterija vladavine prava u okvirima Poglavlja 23 i 24. Osnovni princip je da svaki dan šutnje košta Crnu Goru stvarni novac — u vidu viših troškova zaduživanja, izgubljenih investicija i odložene EU integracije — i Ministarstvo finansija treba da predvodi kvantifikaciju i komunikaciju tih troškova kako bi prisililo vladu na akciju.
key_changes_mne: Uspostaviti međuministarsku Radnu grupu za ekonomski uticaj kojom predsjedava Ministarstvo finansija radi kvantifikovanja i praćenja fiskalnih posljedica skandala na sedmičnoj osnovi
Naložiti hitno smjenjivanje zvaničnika odgovornih za propust u sprovodnju zakona, javno predstavljeno kao neophodan uslov za održavanje kreditnog rejtinga Crne Gore na investicionom nivou
Pokrenuti proaktivne prezentacione komunikacije sa 20 najvećih stranih investitora i ključnih analitičara rejting agencija u roku od 14 dana, prezentujući konkretne sanacione mjere
Ubrzati postupke konfiskacije imovine protiv Medenice po Zakonu o oduzimanju imovinske koristi ostvarene krivičnim djelom, usmjeravajući vraćenu imovinu u konsolidovani budžet
Pripremiti i objaviti dopunsku izjavu o fiskalnim rizicima kao aneks budžeta za 2026. godinu, transparentno otkrivajući potencijalni fiskalni uticaj institucionalne krize
Uslovno povezati sve nove investicione sporazume sa UAE sa nezavisnom revizijom dubinske analize, osiguravajući da oslabljena pozicija vlade ne rezultira fiskalno nepovoljnim uslovima
expected_benefits_mne: Suzbijanje povećanja premije suverenog rizika, sa potencijalnom uštedom od 10-20 miliona eura godišnje u troškovima servisiranja duga
Očuvanje plana stranih direktnih investicija demonstriranjem kapaciteta institucionalne samokorekcije međunarodnim investitorima
Prevencija kašnjenja u vremenskom planu pristupanja EU, zaštita pristupa procijenjenih 500+ miliona eura u predpristupnim i budućim strukturnim fondovima
Uspostavljanje precedenta da je fiskalna analiza uticaja obavezan input u sve vladine odgovore na krize
Ojačana fiskalna transparentnost i odgovornost, poboljšavajući poziciju Crne Gore u globalnim indeksima upravljanja
Povraćaj kriminalne imovine za državni budžet kroz ubrzane postupke konfiskacije
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Procjena fiskalnog uticaja i planiranje za nepredviđene situacije mogu se pokrenuti odmah korištenjem postojećih kapaciteta Ministarstva finansija. Proaktivno angažovanje rejting agencija zahtijeva samo političku volju i koordinaciju. Glavni ograničavajući faktor izvodljivosti je politički — zahtijevanje smjenjivanja i predstavljanje odgovornosti kao ekonomskog imperativa zahtijeva od ministra finansija da zauzme konfrontacijski stav unutar kabineta. Međutim, pravni i institucionalni okviri za konfiskaciju imovine, ispunjavanje EU poglavlja i fiskalnu transparentnost već postoje u crnogorskom zakonodavstvu. Međuministarska radna grupa bi zahtijevala odluku sa Sjednice Vlade, ali ne i zakonske izmjene. Ključni rizik je da trenutna politička paraliza — ilustrovana odlaskom premijera u UAE — spriječi čak i ove administrativno jednostavne mjere da budu sprovedene na vrijeme.

assessments.summary_mne: Skandal sa bjegstvom Medenice i neuspjeh vlade da preduzme konkretne mjere odgovornosti predstavljaju ozbiljnu prijetnju za fiskalne i ekonomske izglede Crne Gore. Iako nije fiskalna odluka per se, institucionalni kolaps koji signalizira — osuđeni pripadnik organizovanog kriminala koji ismijava državu sa društvenih mreža dok se Interpolova crvena potjernica ne sprovodi, u kombinaciji sa odlaskom premijera u UAE i odbijanjem direktora policije da podnese ostavku — direktno potkopava povjerenje investitora, izgledе za pristupanje EU (posebno poglavlja 23 i 24 o pravosuđu i osnovnim pravima, te poglavlje 5 o javnim nabavkama), percepciju suverenog rizika i kredibilitet okvira vladavine prava Crne Gore na kojem u krajnjoj liniji zavise svi prilivi stranog kapitala.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj skandal predstavlja materijalnu prijetnju za ekonomski kredibilitet Crne Gore i trajektoriju pristupanja EU. Nebavljenje vlade rizikuje sniženje kreditnog rejtinga, bijeg stranih investicija i zaustavljene pregovore sa EU — što bi sve direktno oštetilo fiskalnu poziciju. Ministarstvo finansija poziva na hitne mjere institucionalne odgovornosti i transparentan plan sanacije kako bi se ograničile ekonomske posljedice.
key_concerns_mne: Ozbiljna šteta za povjerenje stranih investitora u vladavinu prava Crne Gore, što potencijalno smanjuje prilive stranih direktnih investicija za 5-15% u periodu 2026-2027, sa kaskadnim efektima na prihode od poreza na dobit i PDV-a

Visok rizik od negativne ocjene u narednom izvještaju o napretku Evropske komisije, što potencijalno odgađa privremeno zatvaranje poglavlja 23/24 i blokira pristup pretpristupnim i eventualnim strukturnim fondovima vrijednim stotina miliona eura

Potencijalno sniženje kreditnog rejtinga suverena ili revizija izgleda na negativan od strane Moody's, S&P ili Fitch agencija, što povećava troškove servisiranja duga na javni dug Crne Gore od ~4 milijarde eura za procijenjenih 25-50 baznih poena po stepenu

Oslabljena pregovaračka pozicija sa UAE i drugim investitorima iz Zaljeva tokom posjete premijera Spajića, što potencijalno rezultira manje povoljnim uslovima za bilo koje investicione sporazume ili ugovore o javno-privatnom partnerstvu koji su u fazi pregovaranja

Prolongirana institucionalna neizvjesnost smanjuje povjerenje u rezervacije za turističku sezonu 2026 — turizam doprinosi sa približno 25% BDP-a i predstavlja najveći pojedinačni izvor prihoda od PDV-a
Erozija javnog povjerenja u državne institucije može povećati poresku neposlušnost i aktivnosti u neformalnoj ekonomiji, smanjujući poresku bazu

Rizik da skandal pruži politički paravan za odgođene fiskalne reforme (modernizacija poreske administracije, penzijska reforma, racionalizacija javnih plata) kako se pažnja vlade troši na upravljanje krizom
recommendations_mne: Izdati hitnu procjenu fiskalnog uticaja skandala, kvantifikujući potencijalne gubitke prihoda od smanjenih stranih direktnih investicija, turizma i povećanih troškova zaduživanja, koja će biti predstavljena Fiskalnom vijeću u roku od 30 dana

Zahtijevati hitne, konkretne akcije odgovornosti (smjene, krivične istrage o policijskim propustima) kako bi se signalizirala institucionalna samokorekcija — eksplicitno predstavljajući ovo kao ekonomski imperativ, a ne samo bezbjednosno pitanje
Proaktivno kontaktirati agencije za kreditni rejting da se predstavi vladin plan sanacije prije nego što one pokrenu vlastitu reviziju; uključiti stres testove fiskalne otpornosti u prezentaciju

Ubrzati angažman sa DG NEAR Evropske komisije da se predstavi kredibilan akcioni plan za vladavinu prava, specifično ciljajući mjerila iz poglavlja 23/24, kako bi se spriječilo da skandal poremeti hronologiju pristupanja

Naručiti nezavisnu reviziju svih tekućih JPP i investicionih pregovora sa UAE entitetima kako bi se osiguralo da Crna Gora ne popušta po pitanju prekomjernih fiskalnih uslova zbog oslabljene pregovaračke pozicije

Aktivirati kontingentno budžetsko planiranje koje modelira scenarij pada stranih direktnih investicija od 5-10% i pada turističkih prihoda od 3-5% za 2026. godinu, identificirajući stavke rashoda koje se mogu reprorizirati

Ojačati okvir za borbu protiv pranja novca i procedure za povraćaj imovine — ako Medenica ima imovinu u Crnoj Gori, odmah pokrenuti postupke konfiskacije kako bi se demonstriralo da se zločin ne isplati i kako bi se sredstva vratila u državni budžet

## PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT
### Skupština Crne Gore — Emergency Plenary Session
### Subject: Government Accountability in the Medenica Fugitive Scandal
### Date: 16 February 2026

---

### I. OPENING — FRAMING THE CRISIS

This session convenes to synthesize the assessments of eight government ministries regarding the ongoing Medenica fugitive scandal and the government's response — or, more precisely, the government's conspicuous absence of response.

The facts are undisputed and damning: Miloš Medenica, convicted on 28 January 2026 to 10 years' imprisonment for organized crime, has vanished from house arrest. A person claiming to be Medenica has appeared on national television and has been posting on social media mocking the police. An Interpol Red Notice remains active and unenforced. The Police Director has refused to resign. The Prime Minister departed for the United Arab Emirates after issuing a single statement. President Milatović has publicly demanded dismissals or the Prime Minister's own resignation. No criminal investigation into the police failures has been announced. No official has been dismissed or suspended.

Every ministry — without exception — has returned a negative or strongly negative assessment. This unanimity is itself extraordinary and warrants the Parliament's gravest attention.

---

### II. THE CORE INSTITUTIONAL FAILURE — MINISTRIES OF JUSTICE AND INTERIOR

The Ministry of Justice delivers the most severe indictment, scoring the crisis at 1 out of 10 and characterizing it as "a catastrophic failure of the rule of law." The Ministry frames the escape as a violation of the foundational principle enshrined in Article 1 of the Constitution — the rule of law itself. The Ministry identifies ten specific concerns, ranging from the unenforced court sentence to potential ECHR liability if the fugitive harms third parties. The Ministry's central argument is that a state incapable of enforcing its own criminal court judgments has ceased to function as a state in any meaningful constitutional sense.

The Ministry of Justice recommends immediate convening of the National Security Council, dismissal of the Police Director, activation of the Special State Prosecutor's Office, emergency legislative amendments to prohibit house arrest for serious organized crime convictions, and establishment of a 90-day parliamentary inquiry committee.

The Ministry of Interior arrives at the same score — 1 out of 10 — and offers the most operationally detailed assessment. The Ministry identifies what it calls a "multi-layered failure" of its own core functions: house arrest supervision, fugitive tracking, digital intelligence, and border security. The Ministry makes an analytically critical point: if Medenica has left Montenegro, border controls failed; if he remains in-country, domestic policing failed. Either way, the Ministry of Interior's operational capacity is fundamentally compromised.

The Ministry of Interior's self-assessment is notable for its candor. It explicitly identifies potential criminal liability within the police supervision chain and calls for activation of the Internal Control department with full access to operational records and communication logs. The Ministry also calls for immediate GPS-enabled electronic monitoring for all high-sentence house arrest cases — an implicit admission that current monitoring is inadequate.

**Parliament notes:** The two ministries with the most direct institutional responsibility for this failure have produced the most damning assessments. Neither attempts to minimize or deflect. This candor, while commendable, underscores the severity of the crisis — when institutions indict themselves this thoroughly, the dysfunction is beyond the stage of spin management.

---

### III. EU ACCESSION AND INTERNATIONAL STANDING — MINISTRY OF EU INTEGRATION

The Ministry of EU Integration scores the crisis at 2 out of 10 — strongly negative — and frames it as an existential threat to Montenegro's frontrunner status in the Western Balkans accession process. The Ministry's core argument is strategic: Chapters 23 and 24, which the European Commission has consistently identified as Montenegro's critical benchmarks, are now subject to a real-world stress test that the government is visibly failing.

The Ministry warns that the government's non-response — no dismissals, no inquiry, no corrective plan — will be interpreted by the European Commission not as delay but as absence of political will. This is a crucial distinction: Brussels can tolerate slow reform; it cannot tolerate demonstrated indifference to reform.

The Ministry further warns that Montenegro's credibility gap could have spillover effects on the broader EU enlargement dynamic, potentially providing ammunition to enlargement skeptics within the EU who argue that Western Balkans candidates are not institutionally ready.

The Ministry of EU Integration recommends establishing an independent commission of inquiry with EU-standard terms of reference, urgent briefings to the European Commission's DG NEAR, technical assistance requests for electronic monitoring reform, and an emergency session of the National Council for European Integration to demonstrate cross-party commitment.

**Parliament notes:** The Ministry's recommendation to "control the narrative" with Brussels before the Commission forms its own assessment is pragmatically sound but requires something to narrate. Without concrete accountability measures, proactive communication becomes an exercise in conveying the government's own impotence.

---

### IV. ECONOMIC AND FISCAL CONSEQUENCES — MINISTRIES OF FINANCE AND ECONOMY

The Ministry of Finance (2/10) and the Ministry of Economy (2/10) converge on a stark economic assessment. Both frame the scandal as a direct threat to Montenegro's investment climate, arguing that rule-of-law credibility is the foundational infrastructure upon which all foreign capital flows depend.

The Ministry of Finance provides the most quantified risk assessment: potential FDI reduction of 5-15% in 2026-2027, possible sovereign credit rating downgrade increasing debt servicing costs by 25-50 basis points per notch on approximately €4 billion in public debt, and tourism revenue decline of 3-5% during the critical 2026 season. The Ministry explicitly identifies the Prime Minister's UAE trip as potentially compromising active investment negotiations — arguing that a government visibly unable to enforce its own court orders is in a weakened bargaining position.

The Ministry of Economy broadens the analysis to encompass the labor market, warning that brain drain will accelerate as skilled workers and professionals draw conclusions about institutional integrity. The Ministry frames the scandal's economic impact as a confidence shock — not a policy failure but a credibility failure that reprices Montenegro's risk profile across all economic dimensions.

Both ministries call for investor outreach, fiscal contingency planning, and — critically — framing accountability measures as economic imperatives, not just security matters.

The Ministry of Finance makes a particularly pointed recommendation: if Medenica has assets in Montenegro, initiate confiscation proceedings immediately. This serves dual purposes — demonstrating that crime does not pay, and recovering funds for the state budget.

---

### V. SECTORAL COLLATERAL DAMAGE — TOURISM, ENVIRONMENT, HEALTH, AND EDUCATION

Four ministries assess the crisis as 'negative' at 3/10, reflecting severe indirect damage to their sectors:

**The Ministry of Tourism** warns that international media coverage by OCCRP and Balkan Insight reaches precisely the Western European markets that Montenegro's tourism strategy targets. With the 2026 summer season only three months away, the scandal hits during the critical booking window. The Ministry notes potential impacts on Kotor Bay cruise schedules, tourism-linked real estate investment confidence, and seasonal employment along the Adriatic coast. The Ministry's recommendation for crisis communication protocols with international tour operators is operationally urgent.

**The Ministry of Environment** makes a structurally important argument: a government that cannot track a convicted criminal under house arrest cannot credibly claim it will enforce illegal construction demolition orders, prosecute environmental crimes, or implement complex EU environmental directives. The Ministry warns that the enforcement credibility gap emboldens environmental offenders who already operate with near-impunity. The Ministry calls for a moratorium on spatial planning approvals in protected zones until governance capacity is restored — a dramatic but arguably proportionate recommendation.

**The Ministry of Health** identifies cascading effects on health reform legislation, EU Chapter 28 progress, pharmaceutical procurement integrity, health workforce retention, and public trust in health institutions. The Ministry's concern about organized crime impunity enabling pharmaceutical supply chain corruption is specific and credible.

**The Ministry of Education** raises the most poignant long-term concern: how to teach civic education credibly when students are witnessing systemic institutional failure with zero accountability. The Ministry recommends turning the crisis into a pedagogical opportunity through updated civic education case studies — a constructive suggestion that also serves as implicit commentary on the depth of the damage.

---

### VI. OPPOSITION AND CIVIL SOCIETY PERSPECTIVES

The parliamentary record must reflect that external voices have been more forceful than the government itself:

President Milatović's public demand for dismissals or the Prime Minister's resignation represents an extraordinary exercise of presidential moral authority. While the President's constitutional powers are limited, the public intervention signals that the head of state considers the government's response constitutionally inadequate.

Former Prime Minister Abazović's characterization of the situation as "total collapse of the security system" and the "most bungled government in history" — while carrying the expected political valence of opposition rhetoric — is substantively aligned with every ministry's own assessment. When a government's internal evaluations and its harshest critics reach the same conclusion, the assessment is beyond partisan dispute.

Human Rights Action's demand for a criminal investigation into police failures represents the civil society accountability function operating as designed. The Ministry of EU Integration correctly notes that if this demand is ignored, it will be flagged in European Commission reporting as insufficient engagement with independent oversight.

The opposition's structural argument — that the government has demonstrated systemic incapacity rather than an isolated operational failure — finds support in the pattern of non-response: no dismissals, no inquiry announced, no emergency security council session, no legislative response, no comprehensive public statement. The government's silence is itself an institutional failure compounding the operational one.

---

### VII. POINTS OF CONSENSUS

This Parliament records the following points on which all assessed ministries are in full agreement:

1. The Medenica escape constitutes a fundamental rule-of-law failure.
2. The government's non-response is unacceptable and compounds the damage.
3. The Police Director's position is untenable.
4. The Prime Minister's departure to the UAE during the crisis was, at minimum, a severe error of judgment.
5. Criminal investigation into the circumstances of the escape is necessary.
6. EU accession prospects face serious damage across multiple chapters.
7. Immediate, visible accountability actions are a prerequisite for any credibility recovery.
8. International partners must be proactively engaged before they form independent negative assessments.

---

### VIII. POINTS OF CONTENTION

The Parliament identifies the following unresolved disagreements:

1. Whether the crisis demands structural institutional redesign (new agencies, firewalled units) or targeted corrective action within existing frameworks.
2. The sequencing of crisis response — operational security measures vs. political accountability vs. international communication.
3. Whether emergency legislation restricting house arrest should be fast-tracked or carefully deliberated.
4. The degree to which civil society should be formally integrated into oversight mechanisms during the crisis.
5. Whether the PM's UAE trip serves any legitimate state interest or constitutes pure abdication.

---

### IX. OVERALL PARLIAMENTARY ASSESSMENT

This Parliament finds that the Medenica fugitive scandal and the government's response to it constitute a **strongly negative** development for Montenegro across all dimensions of governance — constitutional, security, judicial, economic, fiscal, diplomatic, and social.

The unanimity of ministerial condemnation is without recent precedent. When the Ministry of Interior effectively indicts its own operational capacity, when the Ministry of Justice declares a constitutional crisis, when the Ministry of Finance models sovereign credit downgrades, and when even ministries with no direct security mandate assess systemic damage to their domains — the Parliament is confronting not an isolated incident but a governance inflection point.

The government's silence is not a strategy. It is an abdication. Every day without concrete accountability measures — dismissals, criminal investigations, an independent inquiry, a comprehensive public statement — widens the credibility gap with citizens, with Brussels, with investors, and with the international community.

This Parliament calls on the government to act. The assessments of its own ministries demand nothing less.

---

*Record of proceedings closed. All ministry assessments entered into the parliamentary record in full.*

blind_spots: No ministry examined whether the original house arrest decision (rather than pretrial detention or immediate imprisonment) for a convicted organized crime figure was itself a systemic judicial failure — who approved house arrest for a 10-year sentence and under what legal authority?

None of the assessments investigated the potential complicity angle in sufficient depth — how does a convicted person simply vanish from monitored house arrest without inside assistance? The corruption dimension is underexplored.
The Ministry of Interior assessment fails to address whether Medenica's passport was actually seized and whether border exit records have been checked — basic operational questions left unanswered.

No ministry addressed the media ethics and legal implications of TV Vijesti broadcasting an appearance by a wanted fugitive — did the network have a legal obligation to report his location to authorities?

The role of the Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) is barely examined — this institution, created specifically for organized crime and high-level corruption, appears completely absent from the response.
No assessment addresses the National Security Council's apparent failure to convene, which is a separate institutional failure beyond the PM's personal departure.

The potential connections between Medenica's organized crime network and political actors are entirely unaddressed — in a country where organized crime and politics have historically intersected, this is a glaring omission.
No ministry examined the adequacy of Montenegro's witness protection and convicted person monitoring infrastructure — is electronic monitoring actually deployed and functional?

critic_report.overall_analysis:
This is not a 'government decision' in the traditional sense — it is the absence of a government decision, which is itself the most damning indictment possible. The Montenegrin government's non-response to the escape of a convicted organized crime figure constitutes a de facto policy of tolerating institutional collapse.

The facts are staggering: a person sentenced to 10 years for organized crime vanishes from house arrest, appears on national television, mocks police on social media, and the government's response is for the Prime Minister to board a plane to the UAE. This is not governance failure — it is governance abandonment.

The ministry assessments are, on the whole, competent and thorough in mapping the downstream consequences across their respective domains. The Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Interior correctly assign the lowest possible scores. However, the assessments collectively suffer from a notable weakness: they are better at cataloging the damage than at diagnosing the root cause. Every ministry discusses the 'signal' this sends, but none adequately confronts the possibility that this is not a signal of dysfunction but evidence of a system operating as certain actors intend it to.

The uncomfortable question none of the ministries asks directly: Was this escape facilitated? In the Western Balkans context, where the nexus between organized crime, intelligence services, and political power is well-documented by OCCRP, Transparency International, and EU monitoring bodies, the assumption of mere incompetence is dangerously naive. A convicted organized crime figure does not simply walk away from house arrest, appear on prime-time television, and maintain an active social media presence without either (a) catastrophic, almost inconceivable incompetence across multiple agencies simultaneously, or (b) deliberate facilitation by actors within the state apparatus. The ministries' reluctance to name this possibility represents the most significant blind spot in the entire assessment package.

The Health, Education, and Environment assessments, while intellectually rigorous in drawing connections to their domains, risk diluting the core message. The primary story here is not about PISA scores or Natura 2000 designations — it is about whether Montenegro is a functioning state. These ministries would have served the public better with shorter, sharper assessments that centered the rule-of-law crisis rather than using it as a springboard for their pre-existing policy wishlists.

The Finance and Economy assessments are the most grounded in concrete, measurable consequences. The point about credit rating vulnerability and borrowing costs is well-taken — Montenegro's fiscal position cannot absorb the compounding costs of institutional credibility loss.

The EU Integration assessment correctly identifies this as potentially the single most damaging event for Montenegro's accession trajectory in recent years. However, it understates the political dimension within the EU itself: enlargement fatigue is real, and scandals like this provide ammunition to member states already skeptical of Western Balkans accession.

What is most striking about the government's conduct is the brazenly contemptuous attitude toward public accountability. The Police Director refuses to resign — and faces no consequences. The PM issues a single statement and leaves the country — and faces no institutional check. President Milatovic demands action — and is ignored. This pattern reveals that Montenegro's formal accountability mechanisms (parliamentary oversight, prosecutorial independence, internal affairs) are either non-functional or deliberately neutralized.

The Human Rights Action demand for a criminal investigation is the single most important civil society intervention in this crisis, and the government's silence in response to it should alarm EU observers. If civil society's legitimate demands for accountability are ignored with impunity, Montenegro's democratic infrastructure is hollower than its constitutional text suggests.

For ordinary Montenegrin citizens, the message is clear and corrosive: the rules apply to you, not to those with power and connections. This perception — already widespread in Montenegrin society — has now received its most dramatic public confirmation. The long-term damage to social cohesion, institutional trust, and civic engagement may exceed even the economic and diplomatic costs that the ministries have cataloged.

Score of 1/10 for the government's handling: there is essentially nothing positive to identify. The conviction itself was a positive step, but the government has managed to transform a rule-of-law success into a rule-of-law catastrophe through sheer inaction and apparent indifference.

critic_report.overall_analysis_mne:
Ovo nije 'vladina odluka' u tradicionalnom smislu — to je odsustvo vladine odluke, što je samo po sebi najpogubnija moguća optužba. Nereagovanje crnogorske vlade na bjekstvo osuđenog kriminalca predstavlja de facto politiku tolerisanja institucionalnog kolapsa.

Činjenice su zapanjujuće: osoba osuđena na 10 godina za organizovani kriminal nestaje sa kućnog pritvora, pojavljuje se na nacionalnoj televiziji, ismijava policiju na društvenim mrežama, a odgovor vlade je da premijer sjedne u avion za UAE. Ovo nije propust u upravljanju — ovo je napuštanje upravljanja.

Ministarske procjene su, u cjelini, kompetentne i temeljne u mapiranju posljedica širom njihovih nadležnosti. Ministarstvo pravde i Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova pravilno dodjeljuju najniže moguće ocjene. Međutim, procjene kolektivno pate od značajne slabosti: bolje su u katalogizaciji štete nego u dijagnostikovanju osnovnog uzroka. Svako ministarstvo diskutuje o 'signalu' koji ovo šalje, ali nijedno ne suočava se adekvatno sa mogućnošću da ovo nije signal disfunkcije već dokaz sistema koji funkcioniše kako određeni akteri namjeravaju.

Neudobno pitanje koje nijedno ministarstvo ne postavlja direktno: Da li je ovo bjekstvo bilo olakšano? U kontekstu Zapadnog Balkana, gdje je veza između organizovanog kriminala, obavještajnih službi i političke moći dobro dokumentovana od strane OCCRP-a, Transparency International-a i tijela EU za praćenje, pretpostavka o samoj nesposobnosti je opasno naivna. Osuđeni kriminalac ne odlazi jednostavno sa kućnog pritvora, ne pojavljuje se u programu u udarnom terminu i ne održava aktivno prisustvo na društvenim mrežama bez ili (a) katastrofalne, gotovo nezamislive nesposobnosti više agencija istovremeno, ili (b) namjernog olakšavanja od strane aktera unutar državnog aparata. Nevoljkost ministarstava da imenuju ovu mogućnost predstavlja najznačajniju slijepu tačku u cjelokupnom paketu procjena.

Procjene ministarstava zdravlja, obrazovanja i životne sredine, mada intelektualno rigorozne u povezivanju sa svojim oblastima, riskiraju razvodnjavanje osnovne poruke. Primarna priča ovdje nije o PISA rezultatima ili Natura 2000 oznakama — već o tome da li je Crna Gora funkcionalna država. Ova ministarstva bi bolje poslužila javnost sa kraćim, oštrjim procjenama koje su centrirali krizu vladavine prava umjesto da je koriste kao odskočnu dasku za svoje već postojeće liste željenih politika.

Procjene ministarstava finansija i ekonomije su najutemeljenije u konkretnim, mjerljivim posledicama. Poenta o ranjivosti kreditnog rejtinga i troškovima zaduživanja je dobro shvaćena — fiskalna pozicija Crne Gore ne može apsorbovati rastuće troškove gubitka institucionalnog kredibiliteta.

Procjena EU integracija pravilno identifikuje ovo kao potencijalno najštetniji događaj za pristupnu putanju Crne Gore u posljednjim godinama. Međutim, potcjenjuje političku dimenziju unutar same EU: zamor od proširenja je realan, a skandali poput ovog pružaju municiju državama članicama koje su već skeptične prema pristupanju Zapadnog Balkana.

Ono što je najupečatljivije u ponašanju vlade je drsko prezirno držanje prema javnoj odgovornosti. Direktor policije odbija da podnese ostavku — i ne suočava se sa nikakvim posljedicama. Premijer izdaje jednu izjavu i napušta zemlju — i ne suočava se sa nijednom institucionalnom provjerom. Predsjednik Milatović zahtjeva akciju — i biva ignorisan. Ovaj obrazac otkriva da mehanizmi formalne odgovornosti Crne Gore (parlamentarni nadzor, tužilačka nezavisnost, unutrašnji poslovi) ili nisu funkcionalni ili su namjerno neutralisani.

Zahtjev organizacije Human Rights Action za krivičnom istragom je najvažnija intervencija civilnog društva u ovoj krizi, a ćutanje vlade kao odgovor na to treba da zabrine posmatrače EU. Ako se legitimni zahtjevi civilnog društva za odgovornošću ignorišu nekažnjeno, demokratska infrastruktura Crne Gore je šupljija nego što njen ustavni tekst sugeriše.

Za obične crnogorske građane, poruka je jasna i korozivna: pravila važe za vas, ne za one sa moći i vezama. Ova percepcija — već široko rasprostranjena u crnogorskom društvu — sada je dobila svoju najdramatičniju javnu potvrdu. Dugoročna šteta društvenoj koheziji, institucionalnom povjerenju i građanskom angažmanu može premašiti čak i ekonomske i diplomatske troškove koje su ministarstva katalogizovala.

Ocjena 1/10 za vladino postupanje: zapravo nema ničeg pozitivnog što bi se moglo identifikovati. Sama presuda je bio pozitivan korak, ali vlada je uspjela da transformiše uspjeh vladavine prava u katastrofu vladavine prava pukom neakcijom i očiglednom ravnodušnošću.
blind_spots_mne: Nijedno ministarstvo nije ispitalo da li je originalna odluka o kućnom pritvoru (umjesto pritvora prije suđenja ili neposrednog zatvaranja) za osuđenog kriminalca sama po sebi bio sistemski pravosudni neuspjeh — ko je odobrio kućni pritvor za kaznu od 10 godina i pod kojim pravnim ovlašćenjem?

Nijedna procjena nije istražila potencijalnu dimenziju saučesništva u dovoljnoj dubini — kako osuđena osoba jednostavno nestaje sa nadgledanog kućnog pritvora bez pomoći iznutra? Dimenzija korupcije je nedovoljno istražena.

Procjena Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova ne uspijeva da se pozabavi time da li je Medeničin pasoš zaista bio oduzet i da li su granični evidencija izlazaka bile provjerene — osnovna operativna pitanja ostala su bez odgovora.

Nijedno ministarstvo se nije pozabavilo medijskom etikom i pravnim implikacijama toga što je TV Vijesti emitovala pojavljivanje traženog bjegunca — da li je mreža imala zakonsku obavezu da prijavi njegovu lokaciju vlastima?
Uloga Specijalnog državnog tužilaštva (SDT) je jedva ispitana — ova institucija, kreirana specifično za organizovani kriminal i korupciju na visokom nivou, izgleda potpuno odsutna iz odgovora.
Nijedna procjena ne bavi se očiglednim neuspjehom Savjeta za nacionalnu bezbjednost da se sastane, što je odvojen institucionalni neuspjeh van premijerovog ličnog odlaska.

Potencijalne veze između Medeničeve mreže organizovanog kriminala i političkih aktera su potpuno nepomenute — u zemlji gdje su se organizovani kriminal i politika istorijski ukrštali, ovo je upečatljivo propuštanje.
Nijedno ministarstvo nije ispitalo adekvatnost crnogorske infrastrukture za zaštitu svjedoka i praćenje osuđenih osoba — da li se elektronsko nadgledanje zaista primjenjuje i funkcionalno je?
Obavještajne službe (ANB — Agencija za nacionalnu bezbjednost) su potpuno odsutne iz svih procjena uprkos svom mandatu da prate prijetnje organizovanog kriminala.
Nijedna procjena ne razmatra da li bi ovaj skandal mogao pokrenuti parlamentarno glasanje o nepovjerenju i koje bi bile ustavne i upravljačke implikacije toga.

counter_proposal.title: Emergency Rule-of-Law Restoration and Institutional Accountability Framework
counter_proposal.executive_summary: The AI Government of Montenegro would treat the Medenica fugitive scandal as a first-order national crisis requiring immediate, visible accountability (dismissals and criminal investigations), a unified multi-agency fugitive apprehension operation, and structural reforms to prevent recurrence — all communicated transparently to domestic and international audiences within 72 hours. Rather than silence and political avoidance, the response would explicitly link rule-of-law restoration to Montenegro's economic survival, EU accession trajectory, and the continuity of government functions across all sectors, deploying crisis-resilient governance mechanisms to prevent institutional paralysis from cascading into health, education, environmental, tourism, and fiscal damage.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The unified counter-proposal is built on the Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Interior assessments as its backbone — this is fundamentally a rule-of-law and security crisis — while integrating the economic, diplomatic, and sectoral resilience frameworks proposed by the other ministries.

**PILLAR 1: IMMEDIATE ACCOUNTABILITY (Days 1-7)**

The Police Director must be dismissed immediately, along with the suspension of all officers in the direct supervisory chain responsible for Medenica's house arrest. This is not optional — it is the minimum credible signal of institutional seriousness. The Ministry of Finance correctly identifies that every day without visible accountability increases sovereign risk premiums and erodes investor confidence. The Ministry of EU Integration warns that the European Commission will interpret silence as absence of political will. The Ministry of Tourism notes the 2026 summer booking window is closing. All roads lead to the same conclusion: dismissals within 48 hours.

Simultaneously, the Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) must open a formal criminal investigation into the circumstances of the escape, examining potential dereliction of duty, abuse of office, and aiding a fugitive within the police supervision chain. The Anti-Corruption Agency (ASK) should conduct asset and communications audits of all officials involved. The Internal Control department of the police must launch a parallel internal affairs investigation. These are not political gestures — they are legal obligations under Montenegrin law when a convicted person escapes state custody.

The Prime Minister must return from the UAE and convene an emergency session of the Council for National Security within 72 hours. This session must produce a public action plan with specific names, timelines, and accountability mechanisms. A single statement followed by international travel is not governance — it is abdication.

**PILLAR 2: UNIFIED FUGITIVE APPREHENSION OPERATION (Days 1-30)**

A dedicated inter-agency Fugitive Apprehension Task Force must be established under the direct authority of the Deputy Prime Minister for Security, combining the Police Directorate, the National Security Agency (ANB), border police, and the Interpol National Central Bureau in Podgorica. This task force must have a single operational commander, daily reporting requirements, and full access to digital intelligence capabilities.

The fugitive's social media activity and television appearance represent actionable intelligence. Coordination with platform providers and telecommunications companies through established legal channels (Mutual Legal Assistance Treaties, European Investigation Order equivalents) must be activated immediately. Diplomatic engagement with all plausible destination countries — particularly those in the Western Balkans region and the UAE — must be elevated to ministerial level.

A 90-day audit of all border crossing points must be initiated, reviewing biometric systems, watchlist integration, and officer accountability protocols. If Medenica crossed a border, the failure is in border management; if he remains in-country, the failure is in domestic policing. Either way, the vulnerability must be identified and closed.

**PILLAR 3: STRUCTURAL LEGAL AND INSTITUTIONAL REFORM (Days 7-180)**

The crisis exposes a specific, fixable vulnerability: the house arrest regime for high-risk organized crime convicts is fundamentally inadequate. An emergency legislative package must be introduced within 14 days containing three elements: (a) prohibition of house arrest for persons convicted of organized crime offenses with sentences exceeding 5 years; (b) mandatory real-time GPS electronic monitoring with automated alerts for all remaining house arrest arrangements; and (c) statutory accountability triggers requiring automatic suspension of supervising officers when a detained person absconds.

An independent inquiry commission must be established within 72 hours, with EU observer participation and civil society representation (including Human Rights Action and MANS), mandated to report publicly within 60 days. This commission must have subpoena power and access to all operational records.

A mandatory audit of all current house arrest arrangements for persons convicted of organized crime, corruption, and violent offenses must be completed within 30 days to identify and close parallel vulnerabilities before they produce additional scandals.

**PILLAR 4: EU ACCESSION DAMAGE CONTROL AND ACCELERATION (Days 1-60)**

The Ministry of EU Integration's proposal forms the core of this pillar. An emergency briefing for the EU Delegation in Podgorica and DG NEAR in Brussels must occur within 72 hours — before the Commission forms its own assessment. Montenegro must control the narrative by presenting concrete corrective actions, not waiting to be judged.

A formal request for TAIEX expert missions on enforcement of criminal sanctions and electronic monitoring must be submitted within 14 days. Updated Action Plans for Chapters 23 and 24, incorporating specific corrective measures arising from this case, must be submitted to the Commission within 30 days.

The National Council for European Integration must convene in emergency session to publicly reaffirm cross-party commitment to rule-of-law reform. This is one of the few mechanisms that can demonstrate political consensus despite the current fractured political landscape.

Mandatory public quarterly reporting on the enforcement status of all organized crime and high-level corruption convictions must be instituted as a permanent transparency measure.

**PILLAR 5: ECONOMIC AND FISCAL DAMAGE CONTAINMENT (Days 1-90)**

The Ministry of Finance's framing is critical: this scandal has quantifiable fiscal consequences. A cross-ministerial Economic Impact Task Force, chaired by the Ministry of Finance, must be established to monitor the fiscal fallout on a weekly basis — tracking FDI pipeline status, tourism forward bookings, and sovereign risk indicators.

Proactive engagement with credit rating agencies (Moody's, S&P, Fitch) must occur within 14 days, presenting the government's remediation plan before agencies initiate their own reviews. Contingency budget planning must model a 5-10% FDI shortfall and 3-5% tourism revenue decline for 2026.

Asset confiscation proceedings against Medenica under the Law on Seizure and Confiscation of Material Gain Derived from Criminal Activity must be fast-tracked. Any ongoing investment negotiations with UAE entities must undergo independent due diligence review to ensure Montenegro's weakened bargaining position does not result in fiscally disadvantageous terms.

A rapid-response investor relations unit within the Ministry of Economy must proactively contact the top 50 foreign investors within 14 days to address concerns and present corrective measures.

**PILLAR 6: SECTORAL RESILIENCE — INSULATING GOVERNMENT FUNCTIONS (Days 1-90)**

The Health, Education, Environment, and Tourism ministries all correctly identify the same systemic risk: a government consumed by crisis cannot govern. The unified response addresses this through crisis-resilient governance mechanisms:

Technical steering committees with delegated authority must be established for EU Chapter negotiations across all domains — Chapter 27 (Environment), Chapter 28 (Health), Chapter 26 (Education) — empowered to advance benchmarks even if cabinet-level decision-making is disrupted. These committees must have pre-authorized mandates that survive ministerial reshuffles.

The Ministry of Environment's proposal for an immediate moratorium on spatial planning approvals in protected coastal zones and national park buffer zones is adopted — the risk of irregular approvals under cover of media distraction is real and documented.

The Ministry of Tourism's crisis communication protocol must be activated immediately, with the NTO issuing clear messaging to international tour operators and key source markets separating the law enforcement failure from tourist safety.

The Ministry of Education's emergency graduate retention program (50 competitive fellowships) and updated civic education materials using the crisis as a case study are adopted as concrete, implementable measures that address brain drain and democratic resilience simultaneously.

The Ministry of Health's pharmaceutical procurement integrity audit, conducted in cooperation with the State Audit Institution, is adopted given the documented connections between organized crime and healthcare supply chains in the Western Balkans.

**CRISIS COMMUNICATION FRAMEWORK**

A comprehensive public government statement must be issued within 48 hours — not a single line from the PM, but a detailed document outlining the timeline of failures, interim corrective measures, the accountability framework being applied, and a concrete timeline for structural reforms. This statement must be addressed simultaneously to the Montenegrin public, the European Commission, international investors, and law enforcement partners. Silence is the single most damaging policy choice available, and it must end immediately.

risks_and_tradeoffs: Political will is the binding constraint: Nearly every ministry identified the same obstacle — the current government's apparent unwillingness to hold its own appointees accountable. If the PM does not return and commit to this framework, implementation collapses. This plan assumes political will can be generated through the combined pressure of EU institutions, economic stakeholders, the President, and civil society — but that assumption may not hold.

Dismissing the Police Director without a vetted successor risks a temporary security vacuum. The plan mitigates this by pre-identifying replacement candidates through Internal Control vetting, but transition risk is real.

The emergency legislative package (house arrest prohibition for sentences >5 years) may face constitutional challenge on proportionality grounds. The Ministry of Justice's legal analysis supports its compatibility with ECHR jurisprudence, but parliamentary debate and potential Constitutional Court review could delay implementation.

Proactive Brussels engagement is a double-edged sword: presenting corrective measures demonstrates self-correction capacity, but also formally puts the scandal on the Commission's radar at ministerial level. However, the scandal is already on their radar through OCCRP and Balkan Insight coverage — controlling the narrative is preferable to silence.

The moratorium on spatial planning approvals in protected zones, while environmentally prudent, will face fierce opposition from construction and development interests with significant political influence along the coast. The economic cost of delayed development must be weighed against the risk of irregular approvals.

Contingency budget planning for FDI and tourism shortfalls may become self-fulfilling if leaked or perceived as a signal of expected economic decline. Publication must be carefully framed as prudent fiscal management, not panic.

The graduate retention fellowship program (50 fellowships, €500-750K) addresses a real brain drain risk but is a modest intervention relative to the structural pull factors driving emigration. It should be understood as a signal, not a solution.

Cross-party consensus on rule-of-law reforms, while theoretically achievable given the scandal's severity, may be undermined by opposition parties who prefer to let the government suffer politically rather than cooperate on solutions. The National Council for European Integration session could devolve into political theater rather than producing genuine commitments.

The plan's comprehensiveness is itself a risk: it requires coordinated action across 7+ ministries, Parliament, the Prosecutor's Office, and international partners simultaneously. Montenegro's institutional capacity for this level of parallel execution is limited. Prioritization of Pillars 1 (accountability) and 2 (apprehension) over later pillars may be necessary if implementation bandwidth is constrained.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Okvir za hitnu obnovu vladavine prava i institucionalnu odgovornost
counter_proposal.executive_summary_mne: AI Vlada Crne Gore bi tretirala skandal bjegstva Medenice kao nacionalnu krizu prvog reda koja zahtijeva hitnu, vidljivu odgovornost (smjene i krivične istrage), jedinstvenu višeagencijsku operaciju hvatanja bjegunca i strukturne reforme za sprječavanje ponavljanja — sve transparentno saopšteno domaćoj i međunarodnoj javnosti u roku od 72 sata. Umjesto šutnje i političkog izbjegavanja, odgovor bi eksplicitno povezao obnovu vladavine prava sa ekonomskim opstankom Crne Gore, trajektorijom pristupanja EU i kontinuitetom vladinih funkcija u svim sektorima, primjenjujući mehanizme upravljanja otporne na krize kako bi se spriječila institucionalna paraliza da se proširi na zdravstvo, obrazovanje, životnu sredinu, turizam i fiskalne štete.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal_mne:
Ujedinjeni counter-prijedlog zasnovan je na procjenama Ministarstva pravde i Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova kao okosnici — ovo je fundamentalno kriza vladavine prava i bezbjednosti — uz integraciju ekonomskih, diplomatskih i sektorskih okvira otpornosti koje su predložila ostala ministarstva.

**STUB 1: HITNA ODGOVORNOST (Dani 1-7)**

Direktor policije mora biti odmah razriješen, zajedno sa suspenzijom svih službenika u direktnom nadzornom lancu odgovornih za kućni pritvor Medenice. Ovo nije opciono — to je minimalan kredibilan signal institucionalne ozbiljnosti. Ministarstvo finansija korektno identifikuje da svaki dan bez vidljive odgovornosti povećava premiju za suvereni rizik i narušava povjerenje investitora. Ministarstvo evropskih integracija upozorava da će Evropska komisija šutnju interpretirati kao odsustvo političke volje. Ministarstvo turizma primjećuje da se zatvara prozor za rezervacije za ljetnju sezonu 2026. Svi putevi vode istom zaključku: smjene u roku od 48 sati.

Istovremeno, Specijalno državno tužilaštvo (SDT) mora otvoriti formalnu krivičnu istragu o okolnostima bjegstva, ispitujući potencijalno zanemarivanje dužnosti, zloupotrebu funkcije i pomaganje bjegunku u policijskom nadzornom lancu. Agencija za sprječavanje korupcije (ASK) treba provesti reviziju imovine i komunikacija svih uključenih službenika. Odjeljenje za unutrašnju kontrolu policije mora pokrenuti paralelnu internu istragu. Ovo nisu politički gestovi — to su zakonske obaveze prema crnogorskom zakonodavstvu kada osuđena osoba pobjegne iz državnog pritvora.

Premijer mora da se vrati iz UAE i sazove hitnu sjednicu Savjeta za nacionalnu bezbjednost u roku od 72 sata. Ova sjednica mora proizvesti javni akcioni plan sa konkretnim imenima, vremenskim okvirima i mehanizmima odgovornosti. Jedna izjava praćena međunarodnim putovanjem nije vladanje — to je odricanje.

**STUB 2: JEDINSTVENA OPERACIJA HVATANJA BJEGUNCA (Dani 1-30)**

Posvećena međuagencijska Radna grupa za hvatanje bjegunaca mora biti uspostavljena pod direktnim autoritetom potpredsjednika Vlade za bezbjednost, objedinjavajući Direktorat policije, Agenciju za nacionalnu bezbjednost (ANB), graničnu policiju i Nacionalni centralni biro Interpola u Podgorici. Ova radna grupa mora imati jednog operativnog komandanta, dnevne izvještajne zahtjeve i pun pristup digitalnim obavještajnim kapacitetima.

Aktivnost bjegunca na društvenim mrežama i pojava na televiziji predstavljaju akcione obavještajne podatke. Koordinacija sa provajderima platformi i telekomunikacionim kompanijama kroz uspostavljene pravne kanale (Ugovori o uzajamnoj pravnoj pomoći, ekvivalenti Evropskog istražnog naloga) mora biti aktivirana odmah. Diplomatsko angažovanje sa svim vjerovatnim destinacijskim zemljama — naročito onima u regionu Zapadnog Balkana i UAE — mora biti podignuto na ministarski nivo.

Revizija svih graničnih prelaza u trajanju od 90 dana mora biti pokrenuta, pregledajući biometrijske sisteme, integraciju lista za praćenje i protokole odgovornosti službenika. Ako je Medenica prešao granicu, neuspjeh je u upravljanju granicom; ako ostaje u zemlji, neuspjeh je u domaćem policijskom radu. U svakom slučaju, ranjivost mora biti identifikovana i zatvorena.

**STUB 3: STRUKTURNA PRAVNA I INSTITUCIONALNA REFORMA (Dani 7-180)**

Kriza razotkriva specifičnu, popravljivu ranjivost: režim kućnog pritvora za visokorizične osuđenike za organizovani kriminal je fundamentalno neadekvatan. Hitni zakonodavni paket mora biti uveden u roku od 14 dana sa tri elementa: (a) zabrana kućnog pritvora za lica osuđena za krivična djela organizovanog kriminala sa kaznama preko 5 godina; (b) obavezno GPS elektronsko praćenje u realnom vremenu sa automatskim upozorenjima za sve preostale aranžmane kućnog pritvora; i (c) zakonski mehanizmi odgovornosti koji zahtijevaju automatsku suspenziju nadzornih službenika kada pritvorenika pobjegne.

Nezavisna istražna komisija mora biti uspostavljena u roku od 72 sata, sa učešćem posmatrača EU i predstavnika civilnog društva (uključujući Akciju za ljudska prava i MANS), sa mandatom da javno izvjesti u roku od 60 dana. Ova komisija mora imati ovlašćenje za pozivanje svjedoka i pristup svim operativnim zapisima.

Obavezna revizija svih trenutnih aranžmana kućnog pritvora za lica osuđena za organizovani kriminal, korupciju i nasilna krivična djela mora biti završena u roku od 30 dana kako bi se identifikovale i zatvorile paralelne ranjivosti prije nego što proizvedu dodatne skandale.

**STUB 4: KONTROLA ŠTETE ZA PRISTUPANJE EU I UBRZANJE (Dani 1-60)**

Prijedlog Ministarstva evropskih integracija formira jezgro ovog stuba. Hitni brifing za Delegaciju EU u Podgorici i DG NEAR u Briselu mora se desiti u roku od 72 sata — prije nego što Komisija formira sopstvenu procjenu. Crna Gora mora kontrolisati narativ predstavljajući konkretne korektivne akcije, ne čekajući da bude suđeno.

Formalni zahtjev za TAIEX stručne misije o sprovođenju krivičnih sankcija i elektronskom praćenju mora biti podnesen u roku od 14 dana. Ažurirani Akcioni planovi za Poglavlja 23 i 24, inkorporirajući specifične korektivne mjere proizašle iz ovog slučaja, moraju biti podneseni Komisiji u roku od 30 dana.

Nacionalni savjet za evropske integracije mora se sastati na hitnoj sjednici kako bi javno potvrdio međustranačku posvećenost reformi vladavine prava. Ovo je jedan od rijetkih mehanizama koji može demonstrirati politički konsenzus uprkos trenutnom fragmentiranom političkom pejzažu.

Obavezno javno kvartalno izvještavanje o statusu sprovođenja svih osuđujućih presuda za organizovani kriminal i korupciju na visokom nivou mora biti uspostavljeno kao trajna mjera transparentnosti.

**STUB 5: EKONOMSKO I FISKALNO OGRANIČAVANJE ŠTETE (Dani 1-90)**

Okvir Ministarstva finansija je kritičan: ovaj skandal ima kvantifikovane fiskalne posljedice. Međuministarska Radna grupa za ekonomski uticaj, kojom predsjedava Ministarstvo finansija, mora biti uspostavljena da prati fiskalne posljedice na sedmičnoj osnovi — praćenje statusa FDI pipeline-a, turističkih rezervacija unaprijed i indikatora suverenog rizika.

Proaktivno angažovanje sa agencijama za kreditni rejting (Moody's, S&P, Fitch) mora se desiti u roku od 14 dana, predstavljajući vladinu remedijalnu strategiju prije nego agencije pokrenu sopstvene preglede. Planiranje kontingentnog budžeta mora modelirati pad FDI od 5-10% i pad turističkih prihoda od 3-5% za 2026. godinu.

Postupci oduzimanja imovine protiv Medenice prema Zakonu o oduzimanju imovinske koristi ostvarene krivičnim djelom moraju biti ubrzani. Sve tekuće investicione pregovore sa entitetima iz UAE mora preći nezavisna due diligence revizija kako bi se osiguralo da oslabljena pregovaračka pozicija Crne Gore ne rezultira fiskalno nepovoljnim uslovima.

Jedinica za brzo reagovanje u odnosima sa investitorima u okviru Ministarstva ekonomije mora proaktivno kontaktirati top 50 stranih investitora u roku od 14 dana kako bi se pozabavili zabrinutostima i predstavili korektivne mjere.

**STUB 6: SEKTORSKA OTPORNOST — IZOLOVANJE VLADINIH FUNKCIJA (Dani 1-90)**

Ministarstva zdravlja, obrazovanja, životne sredine i turizma sva korektno identifikuju isti sistemski rizik: vlada konzumirana krizom ne može vladati. Ujedinjeni odgovor se bavi ovim kroz mehanizme upravljanja otporne na krize:

Tehnički upravljački komiteti sa delegiranim autoritetom moraju biti uspostavljeni za pregovore o poglavljima EU kroz sve domene — Poglavlje 27 (Životna sredina), Poglavlje 28 (Zdravstvo), Poglavlje 26 (Obrazovanje) — ovlašćeni da unapređuju benchmarkove čak i ako je donošenje odluka na nivou kabineta poremećeno. Ovi komiteti moraju imati unaprijed autorizovane mandate koji prežive ministarske rekonstrukcije.

Prijedlog Ministarstva životne sredine za hitni moratorijum na odobrenja prostornog planiranja u zaštićenim obalnim zonama i buferskim zonama nacionalnih parkova je usvojen — rizik od nepravilnih odobrenja pod pokrovom medijske distrakcije je realan i dokumentovan.

Protokol krizne komunikacije Ministarstva turizma mora biti aktiviran odmah, sa NTO koja izdaje jasne poruke međunarodnim tour operaterima i ključnim izvorišnim tržištima odvajajući neuspjeh sprovođenja zakona od bezbjednosti turista.

Hitni program zadržavanja diplomanata Ministarstva obrazovanja (50 kompetitivnih stipendija) i ažurirani materijali za građansko obrazovanje koristeći krizu kao studiju slučaja su usvojeni kao konkretne, primjenjive mjere koje istovremeno rješavaju odliv mozgova i demokratsku otpornost.

Revizija integriteta farmaceutskih nabavki Ministarstva zdravlja, sprovedena u saradnji sa Državnom revizorskom institucijom, je usvojena s obzirom na dokumentovane veze između organizovanog kriminala i lanaca snabdijevanja zdravstva na Zapadnom Balkanu.

**OKVIR KRIZNE KOMUNIKACIJE**

Sveobuhvatna javna vladina izjava mora biti objavljena u roku od 48 sati — ne jedna linija od premijera, već detaljan dokument koji opisuje vremensku liniju neuspjeha, privremene korektivne mjere, okvir odgovornosti koji se primjenjuje i konkretan vremenski okvir za strukturne reforme. Ova izjava mora biti upućena istovremeno crnogorskoj javnosti, Evropskoj komisiji, međunarodnim investitorima i partnerima u sprovođenju zakona. Šutnja je najštetnija politička odluka koja je dostupna, i mora se odmah završiti.

risks_and_tradeoffs_mne: Politička volja je ograničavajući faktor: Gotovo svako ministarstvo je identifikovalo istu prepreku — očiglednu nespremnost trenutne vlade da pozove svoje vlastite imenovane osobe na odgovornost. Ako se premijer ne vrati i ne posveti ovom okviru, implementacija propada. Ovaj plan pretpostavlja da politička volja može biti generisana kroz kombinovani pritisak institucija EU, ekonomskih stejkholdera, predsjednika i civilnog društva — ali ta pretpostavka možda neće opstati.

Razrješenje direktora policije bez provjerenog nasljednika rizikuje privremeni bezbjednosni vakuum. Plan ublažava ovo prethodnim identifikovanjem zamjenskih kandidata kroz provjeru Unutrašnje kontrole, ali tranzicioni rizik je realan.

Hitni zakonodavni paket (zabrana kućnog pritvora za kazne >5 godina) može suočiti ustavni izazov na osnovu proporcionalnosti. Pravna analiza Ministarstva pravde podržava njegovu kompatibilnost sa ECHR jurisprudencijom, ali parlamentarna debata i potencijalni pregled Ustavnog suda mogu odložiti implementaciju.

Proaktivno angažovanje sa Briselom je mač sa dvije oštrice: predstavljanje korektivnih mjera demonstrira kapacitet samokorekcije, ali takođe formalno stavlja skandal na radar Komisije na ministarskom nivou. Međutim, skandal je već na njihovom radaru kroz OCCRP i Balkan Insight izvještavanje — kontrolisanje narativa je poželjnije od šutnje.

Moratorijum na odobrenja prostornog planiranja u zaštićenim zonama, iako ekološki razuman, suočit će se sa žestokim protivljenjem građevinskih i razvojnih interesa sa značajnim političkim uticajem duž obale. Ekonomski trošak odloženog razvoja mora biti odvagan protiv rizika od nepravilnih odobrenja.

Kontingentno budžetsko planiranje za padove FDI i turizma može postati samo-ispunjujuće ako procuri ili se percipira kao signal očekivanog ekonomskog pada. Publikacija mora biti pažljivo uokvirena kao razumno fiskalno upravljanje, ne panika.

Program stipendija za zadržavanje diplomanata (50 stipendija, €500-750K) se bavi realnim rizikom odliva mozgova ali je skromna intervencija u odnosu na strukturne faktore privlačnosti koji pokreću emigraciju. Treba ga razumjeti kao signal, ne rješenje.

Međustranački konsenzus o reformama vladavine prava, iako teoretski ostvariv s obzirom na ozbiljnost skandala, može biti potkopan od strane opozicionih stranaka koje više vole da vlada politički pati nego da sarađuju na rješenjima. Sjednica Nacionalnog savjeta za evropske integracije mogla bi degenerirati u politički teatar umjesto da proizvede istinske obaveze.

Sveobuhvatnost plana je sama po sebi rizik: zahtijeva koordinovanu akciju kroz 7+ ministarstava, Skupštinu, Tužilaštvo i međunarodne partnere istovremeno. Crnogorski institucionalni kapacitet za ovaj nivo paralelnog izvršavanja je ograničen. Prioritizacija Stubova 1 (odgovornost) i 2 (hvatanje) nad kasnijim stubovima može biti neophodna ako je propusnost implementacije ograničena.
